name: Return on Ad Spend
description: ROAS measures the revenue generated for every dollar spent on advertising. It's the most important metric for evaluating ad campaign profitability.
improvementTips: Optimize targeting to reach high-intent audiences
Test different ad creatives to find top performers
Adjust bidding strategies based on performance data

faqs.question: What is a good ROAS for e-commerce?
faqs.answer: For most e-commerce businesses, a ROAS of 4x or higher is considered good. However, this depends on your profit margins - businesses with higher margins can be profitable at lower ROAS.

faqs.question: How is ROAS different from ROI?
faqs.answer: ROAS measures revenue per ad dollar spent, while ROI (Return on Investment) measures profit after all costs. ROAS = Revenue/Ad Spend, ROI = (Profit - Cost)/Cost × 100%.

faqs.question: Why is my ROAS different across platforms?
faqs.answer: Each platform has different attribution models, audience demographics, and conversion tracking methods. Platform-reported ROAS may vary from actual ROAS due to these differences.

metricxFeature: Real-time ROAS tracking across Meta, Google, and TikTok with AI-powered optimization recommendations

name: Cost Per Acquisition
description: CPA measures the average cost to acquire a customer or conversion through advertising. Lower CPA means more efficient ad spend.
formula: Total Ad Spend / Number of Conversions
improvementTips: Refine audience targeting to reduce wasted spend
A/B test ad creatives to improve conversion rates
Optimize landing pages for better user experience
Use lookalike audiences based on existing customers

faqs.question: What's a good CPA for my business?
faqs.answer: A good CPA should be lower than your customer's lifetime value (LTV). Aim for CPA that's 1/3 or less of your average order value for single-purchase products.

faqs.question: How do I lower my CPA?
faqs.answer: Focus on improving conversion rates through better targeting, compelling creatives, and optimized landing pages. Also test different bidding strategies and exclude low-performing audiences.

metricxFeature: Track CPA across all campaigns with AI alerts when costs exceed your targets

name: Click-Through Rate
description: CTR measures the percentage of people who click on your ad after seeing it. Higher CTR indicates more engaging ad creative and targeting.
improvementTips: Write compelling headlines that speak to pain points
Test different ad formats (video vs image)

faqs.question: What affects CTR?
faqs.answer: CTR is influenced by ad creative quality, headline copy, targeting accuracy, ad placement, and offer relevance. Better alignment between these factors increases CTR.

faqs.question: Is high CTR always good?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. High CTR with low conversions may indicate clickbait or misleading ads. Focus on quality clicks that convert, not just click volume.

metricxFeature: Monitor CTR trends with AI recommendations for creative optimization

name: Cost Per Mille
description: CPM is the cost per 1,000 ad impressions. It measures how expensive it is to reach your target audience on a platform.
improvementTips: Broaden targeting to increase available inventory
Adjust bidding strategy based on goals

faqs.question: Why does CPM vary so much?
faqs.answer: CPM is affected by audience competition, seasonality (Q4 is most expensive), platform, placement, and targeting specificity. Narrower targeting typically increases CPM.

faqs.question: Should I optimize for CPM?
faqs.answer: CPM optimization is best for brand awareness campaigns. For conversion-focused campaigns, optimize for CPA or ROAS instead.

metricxFeature: Track CPM trends across platforms and identify cost-saving opportunities

name: Cost Per Click
description: CPC measures the average cost each time someone clicks on your ad. Lower CPC means more efficient traffic acquisition.
formula: Total Ad Spend / Number of Clicks

faqs.question: Is lower CPC always better?
faqs.answer: Not always. Cheap clicks that don't convert waste budget. Focus on cost per conversion (CPA) as the ultimate efficiency metric.

faqs.question: How do I reduce CPC?
faqs.answer: Improve ad quality scores by creating relevant, engaging ads. Better CTR typically leads to lower CPC as platforms reward engaging content.

metricxFeature: Monitor CPC across campaigns with automated alerts for cost spikes

name: Conversion Rate
description: Conversion rate measures the percentage of visitors who complete a desired action (purchase, sign-up, etc.) after clicking an ad.

faqs.question: What's a good conversion rate?
faqs.answer: Average e-commerce conversion rates are 1-3%. Top performers achieve 5%+. Your target depends on product type, price point, and traffic quality.

faqs.question: Why is my conversion rate low?
faqs.answer: Common causes: poor landing page experience, slow load times, complicated checkout, unclear value proposition, or mismatched audience targeting.

metricxFeature: Track conversion rates with AI insights on optimization opportunities

name: Average Order Value
description: AOV measures the average amount spent per order. Increasing AOV improves ROAS without increasing ad spend.
improvementTips: Use tiered discounts (spend more, save more)

faqs.question: How do I increase AOV?
faqs.answer: Use upsells, cross-sells, bundles, free shipping thresholds, and quantity discounts. Post-purchase upsells can increase AOV by 10-30%.

faqs.question: What affects AOV?
faqs.answer: Product pricing, catalog mix, promotional strategy, and customer segment all impact AOV. Different traffic sources often have different AOV.

metricxFeature: Track AOV by traffic source to identify highest-value channels

name: Customer Acquisition Cost
description: CAC is the total cost to acquire a new customer, including all marketing and sales expenses. It's broader than CPA.
formula: Total Marketing & Sales Costs / New Customers Acquired

faqs.question: What's the difference between CAC and CPA?
faqs.answer: CAC includes all costs (ads, salaries, tools, etc.) to acquire a customer. CPA typically refers only to advertising costs per conversion.

faqs.question: What's a good LTV:CAC ratio?
faqs.answer: A 3:1 ratio (LTV 3x higher than CAC) is considered healthy. Below 1:1 means you're losing money on each customer.

metricxFeature: Calculate true CAC by combining ad spend with Shopify customer data

name: Customer Lifetime Value
description: LTV predicts the total revenue a customer will generate during their entire relationship with your business.
formula: Average Order Value × Purchase Frequency × Customer Lifespan

faqs.question: Why is LTV important for ads?
faqs.answer: LTV determines how much you can afford to spend acquiring customers. Higher LTV means you can outbid competitors and still be profitable.

faqs.question: How do I increase LTV?
faqs.answer: Focus on retention through great products, customer service, email marketing, loyalty programs, and expanding product offerings.

metricxFeature: Track LTV cohorts by acquisition source to identify most valuable channels

name: Impressions
description: Impressions count the total number of times your ad was displayed, including multiple views by the same person.

benchmarks.context: Impressions vary widely based on budget and goals
benchmarks.note: Focus on impression quality (reaching right audience) over quantity

improvementTips: Increase budget to reach more people
Improve ad quality for better delivery

faqs.question: What's the difference between impressions and reach?
faqs.answer: Impressions count total ad views (including repeats). Reach counts unique people who saw your ad. 1,000 impressions to 500 people = 500 reach.

faqs.question: Are more impressions always better?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. Quality impressions to your target audience matter more than total volume. High impressions with low engagement indicates targeting issues.

metricxFeature: Track impression share and frequency across all platforms

name: Reach
description: Reach measures the number of unique people who saw your ad at least once during a campaign period.
formula: Number of unique users who saw the ad
formulaExample: 50,000 reach = 50,000 unique people saw your ad

benchmarks.context: Reach goals depend on audience size and campaign objectives
benchmarks.note: Balance reach with frequency for optimal impact

faqs.question: How much reach do I need?
faqs.answer: For brand awareness, aim to reach 50-70% of your target audience over time. For conversion campaigns, quality of reach matters more than quantity.

faqs.question: Why is my reach limited?
faqs.answer: Limited reach is often caused by: narrow targeting, low budget, poor ad quality scores, or audience saturation. Check these factors first.

metricxFeature: Monitor reach and frequency balance to avoid ad fatigue

name: Frequency
description: Frequency measures how many times on average each person saw your ad. Too high frequency can cause ad fatigue.
improvementTips: Set frequency caps in campaign settings

faqs.question: What's the ideal ad frequency?
faqs.answer: For most campaigns, 2-4 frequency is optimal. Brand awareness may benefit from higher frequency (4-7), while conversion campaigns should stay lower.

faqs.question: How do I know if frequency is too high?
faqs.answer: Signs of ad fatigue: declining CTR, increasing CPC, negative comments, and decreasing ROAS. Refresh creatives when you see these patterns.

metricxFeature: AI-powered frequency alerts to prevent ad fatigue

name: Attribution
description: Attribution assigns credit to marketing touchpoints that contributed to a conversion. Different models give different insights.

benchmarks.note: No universal benchmarks - compare your data across models

improvementTips: Use longer attribution windows for high-ticket items
Don't over-optimize for any single model

faqs.question: Which attribution model should I use?
faqs.answer: It depends on your business. Last-click is simple but undervalues awareness. Data-driven is most accurate but needs volume. Use multiple models for full picture.

faqs.question: Why do platforms report different conversions?
faqs.answer: Each platform uses its own attribution model and window. A single purchase might be claimed by Meta (7-day click) and Google (30-day click) simultaneously.

metricxFeature: Compare platform-reported vs Shopify-verified attribution across all channels

name: Add to Cart Rate
description: Add to Cart Rate measures the percentage of visitors who add products to their shopping cart. It's a key mid-funnel metric.

faqs.question: What's a good add to cart rate?
faqs.answer: Average e-commerce ATC rate is 5-8%. If yours is below 3%, focus on product pages. Above 10% is excellent.

faqs.question: High ATC but low conversion - why?
faqs.answer: This indicates checkout friction: unexpected costs (shipping, taxes), complicated checkout, lack of payment options, or trust issues.

metricxFeature: Track ATC rates by traffic source to identify high-intent channels

name: Cart Abandonment Rate
description: Cart Abandonment Rate measures the percentage of shoppers who add items to cart but don't complete purchase.

faqs.question: Is 70% cart abandonment normal?
faqs.answer: Yes, the average cart abandonment rate is 69-70%. Focus on reducing it incrementally - even small improvements significantly impact revenue.

faqs.question: How do I recover abandoned carts?
faqs.answer: Use automated email sequences, retargeting ads, and SMS reminders. Offer incentives like free shipping or small discounts in follow-ups.

metricxFeature: Track cart abandonment with AI recommendations for recovery

name: Return on Investment
description: ROI measures the profitability of an investment relative to its cost. Unlike ROAS, ROI accounts for all costs and profits.

faqs.question: What's the difference between ROI and ROAS?
faqs.answer: ROAS = Revenue/Ad Spend (measures ad efficiency). ROI = (Profit-Cost)/Cost × 100 (measures overall profitability including all costs).

faqs.question: What ROI should I target?
faqs.answer: This depends on your business model. Generally, aim for ROI above your cost of capital. For most businesses, 50%+ ROI on marketing is good.

metricxFeature: Calculate true ROI by combining ad data with Shopify costs

name: Quality Score
description: Quality Score (Google Ads) rates the quality of your ads, keywords, and landing pages. Higher scores lead to lower costs.
formulaExample: Quality Score of 7/10 is considered good

components.name: Expected CTR
components.description: Likelihood of your ad being clicked

components.name: Ad Relevance
components.description: How well ad matches search intent

improvementTips: Ensure keyword relevance in ad copy

faqs.question: Why does Quality Score matter?
faqs.answer: Higher Quality Score = lower CPC and better ad positions. Google rewards relevant, high-quality ads with cheaper clicks and more visibility.

faqs.question: How do I improve Quality Score?
faqs.answer: Focus on the three components: improve CTR with compelling ads, ensure ad relevance to keywords, and optimize landing page experience.

metricxFeature: Track Quality Score trends with actionable improvement recommendations

name: Ad Relevance Score
description: Ad Relevance (Meta) measures how well your ad resonates with your target audience based on expected engagement.
formula: Meta's proprietary algorithm (Below Average, Average, Above Average)
formulaExample: Above Average relevance indicates strong audience fit
improvementTips: Ensure landing page matches ad promise

faqs.question: What affects Meta ad relevance?
faqs.answer: Positive engagement (likes, shares, saves), negative feedback (hide ad), and conversion rates all impact your relevance scores.

faqs.question: How do I improve ad relevance?
faqs.answer: Better audience targeting, more engaging creative, clear value proposition, and ensuring ad matches landing page expectations.

metricxFeature: Monitor relevance scores with AI-powered creative recommendations

name: Advertising Cost of Sales
description: ACoS measures ad spend as a percentage of attributed sales. Common in Amazon advertising, but applicable to all e-commerce.
improvementTips: Reduce wasted spend on poor performers

faqs.question: How is ACoS related to ROAS?
faqs.answer: ACoS and ROAS are inverses. ACoS = 1/ROAS × 100. A 20% ACoS equals 5x ROAS. A 25% ACoS equals 4x ROAS.

faqs.question: What ACoS should I target?
faqs.answer: Your target ACoS should be below your profit margin. If margin is 30%, keep ACoS under 30% to stay profitable.

metricxFeature: Track ACoS alongside ROAS for complete profitability picture

name: Total Advertising Cost of Sales
description: TACoS measures ad spend as a percentage of total sales (not just attributed sales). Shows true ad dependency.

faqs.question: Why is TACoS important?
faqs.answer: TACoS shows how dependent your business is on paid ads. Decreasing TACoS while growing revenue means you're building organic momentum.

faqs.question: What's a healthy TACoS trend?
faqs.answer: Ideally, TACoS should decrease over time as organic sales grow. Increasing TACoS may indicate over-reliance on advertising.

metricxFeature: Track TACoS trends to measure organic business growth
